title.children: An El Niño could be declared as early as next week: This is what it looks like when it forms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A baby grand piano that the iconic frontman of Queen, Freddie Mercury, used to compose some of the band's greatest hits has sold at auction in London for more than $3 million. Earlier, Sotheby's sold his original music manuscript for the song Bohemian Rhapsody for more than $2.6 million. The document contains Mercury's handwritten notes in pen and pencil. The auctioneer, Oliver Barker, says Mercury's personal collection has attracted huge interest. "What we've witnessed here at Sotheby's these last few weeks is nothing short of phenomenal," he said. "This has been truly a sale to capture the minds and the hearts of all the public all over the world. By the time the doors closed yesterday on this once-in-a-lifetime month-long exhibition, we had welcomed 140,000 visitors."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Freddie Mercury's prized piano, Bohemian Rhapsody draft fetch millions at auction

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The opposition says the federal government still has questions to answer about why it did not allow extra Qatar flights into Australia. The airline wanted an extra 28 flights per week into major capital cities, but that was denied in July this year. Transport Minister Catherine King says there were many factors that lead to her decision which was in "the national interest." Shadow Finance Minister Jane Hume told RN Breakfast that answer wasn't good enough. "Quite frankly I don't think that it's any clearer today than it was yesterday, what was behind the decision to deny Qatar Airways additional routes to Australia that would have increased competition and decreased the price of airfares for ordinary Australians." You can listen to the full interview of RN Breakfast at the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Still a lot of questions to answer' over Qatar, Hume says

featuredLink.title: Hume: 'still a lot of questions to answer' over Qatar - ABC listen

props.alt: A close up of Jane Hume speaking.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
By political reporter Tom Lowrey Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is expected to sit down with China's Premier Li Qiang on the sidelines of the ASEAN summit in Jakarta this morning, in what would be the highest-level meeting between the two countries this year. Premier Li is China's second-highest-ranking official after President Xi Jinping, who has opted not to attend a series of global summits underway this week. There had been hopes Albanese might meet President Xi at the G20 leader's summit in Delhi this weekend, re-creating a significant meeting of the two leaders at last year's G20 summit in Bali. But with that no longer an option, it is now expected the PM will meet Premier Li instead. It's anticipated the two leaders would meet ahead of the East Asia Summit, which brings together South-East Asian leaders with leaders of countries like Australia, Japan, China, Russia and the USA. While diplomatic and trade relations between Australia and China have improved substantially in recent months, there are some substantial issues that might be raised. Trade barriers remain in place on Australian wine exports, and ministers have spoken out in recent months calling for their removal. Two Australians also remain detained in Beijing —
journalist Cheng Lei, and writer Dr Yang Hengjun. The government has openly called for both Australians to be reunited with their families, and Foreign Minister Penny Wong yesterday told the ABC that officials were continuing that pressure. "We are deeply concerned about Ms Cheng Lei and Dr Yang, as are so many Australians," she said. "And we have continued to raise with our counterparts at every level the desire of Australia to see both Ms Cheng Lei and Dr Yang reunited with their families. "We'll continue to make those representations."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM expected to meet China's second-highest-ranking official in Indonesia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello! Rachel Pupazzoni joining Kate on the blog as we're in for a busy day today. Before we hear from Philip Lowe for the last time, I thought I'd jump in with a bit more on another leadership change. No, not Qantas. That other, other leadership change that's made headlines recently. Remember last week when Andrew Forrest announced the chief executive of Fortescue Metals Group, Fiona Hick was out and Dino Otranto was now in the top job - on the same morning the top 10 ASX listed company was due to reveal it's full year results? On that day, they held their media and analyst briefing before they even published their annual results to the market (because there was a whole lot of name replacing going on in the documents) - it made for an engaging call that morning. By the way, Ms Hick is not the only exit - hardly a day has gone by since last Monday where another FMG high level executive or staffer hasn't left. But looking forward, Mr Otranto (title now CEO FMG Metals) and Mark Hutchison (CEO FMG Energy) have now held another briefing with analysts and our good friends at UBS have sent over a note from that discussion. The note from UBS analysts Lachlan Shaw, Levi Spry and Dim Ariyasinghe says: FMG explained that while former CEO Fiona Hick and CFO Christine Milne were highly regarded, the fit had not worked. A quick response was seen as in the best interests of shareholders and governance. Recent leadership changes reflected that the Board had decided the 'fit' of former CEO Fiona Hick and CFO Christine Milne was off, and saw fit from a governance perspective to move quickly to address. Management stability vs FMG's agile/ can-do decision making culture was taken into account. Until recently, FMG had allocated 10 per cent of its net profit after tax to be spent on Fortescue Future Industries projects. That has been removed, along with it the certainty of how much of the iron ore profits would be spent developing decarbonisation technologies. Mr Hutchison has been tasked with delivering five projects by the end of this year. I was chatting with a former FMG insider recently, who said even delivering one is a big ask. So I guess... watch this space. But back to the UBS, note. The analyst team's guidance is to sell FMG shares. We remain sell rated with $15.20/sh PT reflecting near term iron ore price caution on China steel production caps, and uncertainty on Energy project economics and execution risks. Fortescue shares are down slightly today - fetching about $20.33 .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FMG briefs analysts on its plans, after that mass exodus triggered by CEO Fiona Hick last week

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ has increased interest rates on all but one of its credit cards by 0.25 percentage points overnight. Customers with the ANZ Low Rate card will see a 1.25 percentage point increase, taking the interest rate to 13.74%. All credit cards with ANZ are also seeing a 0.75 percentage point increase to its cash advance and balance transfer rates — taking it from 21.24% to 21.99%. The annual fees on three ANZ cards will also increase from November 8 — its Rewards Platinum, Rewards, and Rewards Travel. Here's a breakdown of the interest rate changes on ANZ's credit cards, courtesy of RateCity: Low Rate: +1.25% to 13.74% (Annual fee: $0 for 1 year then $58) First: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $0 for 1 year then $30) Platinum: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $0 for 1 year then $87, or free if spend +$20K yearly) Rewards Platinum: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $95 — increasing to $149 on November 8) Frequent Flyer Platinum: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $425) Rewards Black: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $375) Frequent Flyer Black: +0.25% to 20.49% (Annual fee: $425) Sally Tindall, RateCity.com.au's research director said the credit card fees were hiked by ANZ "in the dead of night". "For some ANZ card holders, this rate rise could pass them by if they’re not paying attention," she said. "In the last six months we’ve seen 10 lenders hike the rates on at least one of their credit cards, while seven lenders have increased annual fees. "This is yet another timely reminder to give your credit card a health check regardless of who the provider is."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ lifts interest rates on all of its credit cards

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has opened lower, down 0.8% to 7,197 points as of 10:25am AEST — the lowest open the ASX has seen in seven days. (For live updates at any time, head to the top of the blog and open the pinned post.) Those jitters from Wall Street overnight about sticky inflation and higher interest rates for longer have flowed through to our session, in response to that stronger-than-expected US services sector figures. Academic and education services and real estate are the only sectors in the black so far — they're up 0.5% and 0.1% respectively. Basic materials is down 2% so far, while industrials has dipped by 0.7%, and consumer cyclicals fell by 0.5%. As for the top five performers so far: Liontown Resources +5.1% Chalice Mining +3.5% Beach Energy +3.1% Viva Energy +1.65 Resmed +1.1% And the bottom five performers: Super Retail Group -6.2% BrainChip Holdings -4% BHP Group -4% Perpetual -3.6% Reliance Worldwide -3.1% (Take BHP's performance with a grain of salt today, though — they are trading ex-dividend.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX falls to 7-day low as Wall Street jitters send miners lower
